<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 379, 144]]<|/det|> # Cambridge IGCSE™ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 202]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 222, 175, 252]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 212, 425, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 722, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 211, 905, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 178, 293]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|> 0625/51 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 260, 317]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[777, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|> May/June 2022 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 1 hour 15 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 401]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 729, 636]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 645, 905, 841]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 645, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the stretching of a spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 120]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 131, 806, 400]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 418, 532, 437]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 450, 144, 469]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 450, 920, 483]]<|/det|>
The metre rule is clamped in position close to the spring. Do **not** change the position of the metre rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 496, 181, 514]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 496, 920, 529]]<|/det|>
Take two readings from the metre rule to determine the unstretched length \(l_0\) of the coiled part of the spring. Use the set square provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 556, 920, 575]]<|/det|>
<form>reading 1 ...................................................... cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 588, 920, 606]]<|/det|>
<form>reading 2 ...................................................... cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 618, 920, 636]]<|/det|>
<form>l_0 = ......................................................... cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 635, 920, 653]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 601, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1. You are provided with an insulating sleeve to place around the metal can while pouring hot water.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 147, 816, 368]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 384, 532, 402]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 415, 144, 433]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 415, 645, 433]]<|/det|>
Use the thermometer to measure the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 445, 920, 464]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\)  ................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 476, 144, 495]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 476, 180, 495]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 476, 551, 495]]<|/det|>
Place the insulating sleeve around the can.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 507, 918, 541]]<|/det|>
Pour hot water into the can until the water level is up to approximately \(2 \text{cm}\) from the top. Place the thermometer in the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 555, 443, 572]]<|/det|>
Remove the insulating sleeve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 585, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
Record, in Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0\). Immediately start the stop-clock.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 631, 920, 664]]<|/det|>
Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the water temperature every 30 s until you have 7 sets of readings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 678, 485, 696]]<|/det|>
Do not empty the can at this stage.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 678, 920, 696]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 559, 89]]<|/det|> Complete the column headings in Table 2.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 103, 541, 120]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[343, 133, 655, 341]]<|/det|>
\(t/\)\(\theta /\)

R_{1} = ............................................................ Include the unit. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 801, 920, 820]]<|/det|> R_{2} = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 633, 89]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance of a wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 120]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 126, 816, 350]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 359, 532, 377]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 390, 144, 409]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 390, 299, 408]]<|/det|> Close the switch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 421, 447, 440]]<|/det|> Measure the current \(I\) in the circuit. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 451, 922, 470]]<|/det|>
I = .................................................... [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 483, 146, 501]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 483, 620, 501]]<|/det|> Place the sliding contact at a distance \(l = 5.0 \text{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{B}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 513, 920, 546]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across the length \(l\) of resistance wire \(\mathbf{BC}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 559, 297, 576]]<|/det|> Open the switch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 588, 920, 621]]<|/det|> Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the resistance \(R\) of \(5.0 \text{cm}\) of the resistance wire using the equation <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 626, 532, 655]]<|/det|> \[R = \frac{V}{I}.\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 664, 299, 682]]<|/det|> Close the switch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 694, 850, 712]]<|/det|> Repeat the procedure in **(b)** using \(l\) values of \(25.0 \text{cm}\), \(45.0 \text{cm}\), \(65.0 \text{cm}\) and \(85.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 724, 297, 742]]<|/det|> Open the switch. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 754, 541, 771]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[279, 782, 719, 927]]<|/det|>
l/ cmV/VR/Ω
5.0
25.0
45.0
65.0

Plot a graph of \(R / \Omega\) (y-axis) against \(l / \text{cm}\) (x-axis). Start both axes at the origin (0,0).

<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the force required to break different beams made from a mixture of sand and cement. All the beams have the same cross-section.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 118, 714, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the force required to break the beams.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 332, 166]]<|/det|>
Fig. 4.1 shows the set-up.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 485, 197]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do this investigation.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 208, 781, 293]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 313, 532, 331]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 345, 420, 363]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 377, 133, 393]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 376, 900, 393]]<|/det|>
a selection of beams made from different ratios of sand and cement and of various lengths

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 392, 475, 409]]<|/det|>
• triangular blocks to support the beams

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 408, 260, 425]]<|/det|>
• a metre rule

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 424, 322, 440]]<|/det|>
• a selection of loads.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 454, 907, 471]]<|/det|>
You can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 484, 920, 518]]<|/det|>
The student takes all the necessary safety precautions. You are **not** required to write about safety precautions.
